description: Alimony is granted to a spouse who lacks sufficient income or resources to support themselves after divorce.
The length of the marriage significantly impacts the amount and duration of alimony awarded.
Courts consider the standard of living established during the marriage when determining alimony payments.
The earning potential of both spouses is assessed to ensure fairness in alimony decisions.
Short-term alimony to support the recipient spouse until they gain education or training to become self-supporting.
Awarded in cases where one spouse is unable to become self-sufficient due to age, health, or other circumstances.
Either spouse can request changes to alimony if there is a significant change in financial circumstances.
Alimony typically ends upon the recipient's remarriage, cohabitation, or the death of either spouse.
Alimony can be granted regardless of which party was at fault for the divorce.
The physical and mental health of both spouses is taken into account when deciding alimony.
As of recent laws, alimony payments are no longer tax-deductible by the payer nor considered taxable income for the recipient.
Child support takes priority over alimony in financial arrangements.
Alimony payments may be reduced or terminated if the recipient spouse starts cohabiting with another person.
One-time alimony payment in lieu of ongoing monthly payments, often used in amicable separations.
In some jurisdictions, the fault in the divorce may influence the amount or decision to award alimony.
Prenuptial agreements can outline or waive alimony terms, but they must be legally enforceable.
Failure to pay alimony can result in legal penalties, including wage garnishment or contempt of court.
Support provided during the divorce proceedings to maintain financial stability until the final decision is made.
Courts can assign an income level to a spouse if they are found to be voluntarily unemployed or underemployed.
A history of domestic violence can influence alimony decisions, often favoring the victimized spouse.
